intro: Apalophlebia, commonly known as the slender mistletoe, is a genus of hemiparasitic plants belonging to the family Viscaceae. These plants are characterized by their small, often scale-like leaves and their ability to derive some of their nutrients from host trees through specialized roots called haustoria. Apalophlebia species are typically found in tropical and subtropical regions, often growing on the branches of other plants. Their flowers are usually small and inconspicuous, producing small, fleshy fruits that are dispersed by birds. Due to their parasitic nature and limited distribution, these plants are of interest in ecological and botanical studies.
